headline: General Motors China JV Woes Trigger Billions In Charges: Details
summary: General Motors Company (NYSE:GM) shares are trading lower on Wednesday after the company concluded that a material impairment of its equity interest in SAIC General Motors Corporation Limited (SGM) is necessary. This decision follows a determination that the value of GM’s investments in certain of its China joint ventures has declined. headline: GM to take $5 billion hit over struggling China joint venture
summary: General Motors (GM) is expected to take a $5 billion hit in non-cash charges over its joint-venture operation in China with SAIC Motor Corp. (600104.SS). Yahoo Finance senior autos reporter Pras Subramanian joins Catalysts to explain the situation, GM's losses, and the automaker's write-downs of the venture and restructuring charges. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Catalysts here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: GM's $5B China hit, Foot Locker earnings, Okta: 3 Stocks In Focus
summary: Automaker General Motors (GM) expects to take over $5 billion in non-cash charges on its joint-venture operations in China with SAIC Motor Corp. (600104.SS). Foot Locker (FL) shares are tumbling in Wednesday's pre-market trading as the footwear retailer cuts its full-year guidance while missing third quarter estimates, citing weak consumer demand. Cloud software operator Okta (OKTA) stock is holding onto gains after beating earnings and revenue estimates for its last quarter. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: Fed chair, Salesforce earnings, GM's $5B hit: 3 Things
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will deliver commentary today, two weeks ahead of the central bank's last policy meeting of the year. US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are rising Wednesday morning ahead of this news, as ADP reported a gain of 146,000 private sector jobs in November. Salesforce (CRM) shares continue to surge by over 11% in pre-market trading after its revenue topped third quarter estimates — $9.44 billion beating expectations for $9.35 billion — coming off of the cloud company's launch of Agentforce in October. General Motors (GM) will take on two non-cash charges totaling $5 billion over its troubled China operations. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: Losses in China lead to $5 billion charge for General Motors as it cuts the value of its assets
summary: The poor performance of General Motors' Chinese joint ventures is forcing the company to write down assets and take a restructuring charge totaling more than $5 billion in the fourth quarter of this year.  In addition, GM will take $2.7 billion worth of restructuring charges, most of it during the fourth quarter.  The noncash charges will reduce the company's net income, but they will not affect adjusted pretax earnings, GM said in the filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

raw.headline: Losses in China lead to $5 billion charge for General Motors as it cuts the value of its assets
raw.summary: The poor performance of General Motors' Chinese joint ventures is forcing the company to write down assets and take a restructuring charge totaling more than $5 billion in the fourth quarter of this year.  In addition, GM will take $2.7 billion worth of restructuring charges, most of it during the fourth quarter.  The noncash charges will reduce the company's net income, but they will not affect adjusted pretax earnings, GM said in the filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: GM to take more than $5 billion in charges on China operations
summary: DETROIT (Reuters) -General Motors told shareholders on Wednesday that it would record two non-cash charges totaling more than $5 billion on its joint venture in China, one related to the restructuring of the operation and another reflecting its reduced value.  GM's China division, once a profit engine for the Detroit company, is now losing money.  The Detroit company has struggled to compete with carmakers in China, the world's largest auto market, who have charged past U.S. and European rivals, partly buoyed by government subsidies.

raw.headline: GM to take more than $5 billion in charges on China operations
raw.summary: DETROIT (Reuters) -General Motors told shareholders on Wednesday that it would record two non-cash charges totaling more than $5 billion on its joint venture in China, one related to the restructuring of the operation and another reflecting its reduced value.  GM's China division, once a profit engine for the Detroit company, is now losing money.  The Detroit company has struggled to compete with carmakers in China, the world's largest auto market, who have charged past U.S. and European rivals, partly buoyed by government subsidies.
